Identifying Characteristics: Black head with occasional light dots or markings
Scales on the upper legs are black or brown
Skin on the throat, lower neck, and lower parts of the legs can be yellow, orange, or orange-red to salmon-red—sometimes speckled with darker colors
Size: average between 5’’ and almost 10’’ in length
Biology: Hibernates from November through February or March
Sexual maturity occurs between 14 and 18 years
Mating occurs in both Spring and Fall
In May or June females search for open, sunny nesting sites, preferring sandy banks near moving water
The female digs the nest with her hind feet into which she lays 3 to 18 eggs
The eggs are carefully buried then female camouflages the nest
Female departs from nest and offers no further protection to offspring
Females may not reproduce every year
Most eggs never hatch—nest predation by raccoons, skunks, shrews, foxes, and other predators result in high losses
Hatchlings hatch from their nests in late August or September and move to water
Typically reach adulthood between 14 and 20 years
Diet: Plant matter and animals both on land and in water
Eats prey like beetles, millipedes, and slugs
Consumes specific fungi (Amanita muscaria and Leccinum arcolatum), mosses, grasses, various insects, and also carrion
Habitat: Slow-moving streams containing a sandy bottom and heavily vegetated banks
Soft bottoms and muddy shores of streams are ideal for overwintering
Areas bordering the streams are used for nesting
Spring to summer is spent in open areas including forests, fields, bogs, wet meadows, and beaver ponds
Can be seen basking on logs, sandy shores, or banks
Range: Eastern Canada and the northeastern United States—from Nova Scotia and New Brunswick south through New England, Pennsylvania and northern New Jersey, to northern Virginia
West through southern Quebec, southern Ontario, northern Michigan (northern Lower and Upper Peninsulas), northern and central Wisconsin, to eastern Minnesota
Can also be found in northeastern Iowa (but uncommon)
